DOC.HEAD: Party Chief Jiang Calls For Corruption Fight To Restore Ties with People
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Communist Party renewed his attack on reform movements while officials took steps to halt students' display of support for Romania's revolution. ``The Chinese Communist Party and China are at a critical moment and we should continue to keep the domestic political situation stable,'' party General Secretary Jiang Zemin said Friday. ``The fight against bourgeois-liberalism is a long-term and strenuous task,'' he told a party forum in a speech described as important by the official radio and television, which reported on it at length. A summary was issued by the Xinhua News Agency. It was Jiang's first publicized speech since Romania's hard-line Communist leadership was ousted last week by a popular uprising. Chinese college students celebrated by putting up several protest posters. Authorities since have increased surveillance and political study. Jiang said the party showed its strength by crushing pro-democracy protests in June and ``smashing the efforts by hostile foreign forces to foist on China a so-called peaceful evolution'' away from socialism. Bourgeois-liberalism is the catch-phrase for Western democratic ideas. In private, Chinese party officials have denounced Eastern Europe's turn from communist rule as bourgeois-liberal and revisionist. In his publicized comments Jiang did not mention Romania or the democratic changes that have swept the rest of Eastern Europe. However, his remarks appeared to be directed at the challenge presented by these changes. He also said the party needs to perfect its leadership and strengthen ideological education and discipline. ``The rampant corruption which has come to public notice in recent years has aroused the discontent of the masses,'' Jiang said, ``and effective measures should be adopted to resume the close ties the party once maintained with the masses of the people.'' Despite repeated campaigns in recent years, however, the party has shown itself unable to wipe out corruption stemming from party members' privileged position in society. Xinhua said Jiang stressed ``that the party should trust the masses of the people and depend on them absolutely.'' However, police have stepped up patrols on Beijing college campuses since the Romanian uprising.
